data.title: Latest monaco editor build likely broken
data.body:
Built yesterday fine. Broken just today. 

- All builds https://travis-ci.org/basarat/monaco/builds
- Today's build https://travis-ci.org/basarat/monaco/builds/199465864#L960 Suspect a test definition has gone wonky (or missing) 

```
[02:12:47] Error: /home/travis/build/basarat/monaco/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/welcome/gettingStarted/test/common/gettingStarted.test.ts(13,1): Cannot find name 'suite'.
```

As always, just felt it would be helpful to report early. Love your work / monaco :rose: :heart:

data.body: Switches to using `@types` to manage the typings for a few more packages.

data.title: showOutput: "never" option in tasks.json is not respected
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a task with the `showOutput` property set to `"never"`
2. Run task
3. Output pane will open regardless of setting.

My tasks.json:

```javascript
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "npm",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "never",
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "install",
            "args": ["install"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "update",
            "args": ["update"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "compile",
            "args": ["run", "compile"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "watch",
            "args": ["run", "watch"],
            "isBackground": true,
            "isBuildCommand": true
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Use @types for a few d.ts files in src
data.body: Switches a few modules to using `@types` npm packages for a few `d.ts` files in `src/`.

data.title: Added support for home/end key in IntelliSense
data.body:
This PR adds a support for `home` / `end` keys in IntelliSense. I had basically the very same expectaction / feeling as given in #18656.

Everything is pretty straight-forward except:

* I wasn't able to locate tests for `suggestWidget`, `listWidget`, am I missing something?
* I don't really know how to trigger details view (from end user perspective) so **I couldn't test it**. Please make sure to check it or provide me an example steps on how to trigger it.
* I know nothing about Mac hotkeys, so the default mapping included only home and end key which are present on Windows / Linux.

data.title: Show "Debug Console" automatically when a new debugging session is started
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create workspace with a "Hello, World"-style app (language doesn't matter).
2. Add `launch.json` to the workspace.
3. Switch to any panel tab but "Debug Console".
4. Start debugging.

Expected behavior:
The "Debug Console" tab is shown automatically when the debugger is launched.

Actual behavior:
The currently active tab stays active.

This behavior is really annoying when using a launch configuration that combines `"externalConsole": false` with `"preLaunchTask": "..."`. The "Output" window is shown when the preLaunchTask runs, so you have to go back to "Debug Console" manually every time you start debugging.

data.title: Clean Current File, Clean All Files in Command Palette
data.body:
It'd be lovely if the `Clean` operation (i.e. checkout current file, checkout all files) could be done from the command palette instead of the GUI.

Bonus request: Convert `Clean` from a destructive action into an action that uses the `undo` stack. This removes the warning and makes it more user friendly.

Steps to Reproduce:

2. 3 instances of vs code open 3 different

data.title: Run build task fails
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Win10.0.14393
- PS Version: 5.1.14393.693

Steps to Reproduce:

1. _Tasks: Run build task_.

tasks.json:
```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "powershell",
    "args": [   
        "-ExecutionPolicy",
        "Unrestricted",
        "-NoProfile",
        "-File",
        "${cwd}/Invoke-PostBuildActivities.ps1"       
    ],
    "taskSelector": "-task ",
    "showOutput": "always",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "build",
            "showOutput": "always",
            "isBuildCommand": true
        }
    ]
}
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6840381/22715617/d86eb376-ede5-11e6-9ea2-c6c0f3190134.png)

The script works OK when run directly with _Debug: Continue_.

Any ideas?

Not sure if it should be here or in the PowerShell extension's repo, sorry in advance if this is a wrong place.

Many thanks

data.title: "Scroll lock" in Output doesn't work
data.body:
Whether I have scroll lock toggled on or off, the output pane doesn't scroll with new build output. Seeing this in all of my projects in Insiders. 

- Open the vscode repo
- Open the output pane
- Enable scroll lock
- Build vscode
- New output goes below the output pane viewport, and it doesn't automatically scroll to keep the bottom in view.

data.title: Handle root, network path or disk drive letter
data.body:
Fix for #19382 and #19384

Always preserve root path (/root/path), network path (\\network\path) or disk drive (diskDrive:\path)

Windows tests are passing. Could anyone please check if non windows tests are also passing?

data.title: Changing a theme on a second window also changes the first.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Having multiple separate windows open, one for Markdown and one for code is quite common.  Having appropriate themes for each of those at the same time would be useful.  Thanks.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open first window.  Set theme to "Light" for a Markdown file
2. Open second window. Set theme to "Dark" for code editing.
3. First window theme also changes.

data.title: Tree cheese

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. I cannot currently reliably reproduce this bug in any clean environment. 

I am experiencing a bug concerning VSCode's tree view. Video of the bug is captured in [this Giphy link](http://www.giphy.com/gifs/26gss0EPsl58Yhj32). 

In this video, I am simply clicking (to expand and contract) whichever folder is highlighted. You can see that the children of `templates` changes each time I expand and contract it. 

```
FolderA
|-> FolderB
    |-> Content
```

If I have `FolderA` and `FolderB` expanded, then collapse `FolderA`, the next time I expand `FolderA` it displays some items from `Content` as `FolderA`'s child instead of an expanded `FolderB` with all of `Content` underneath it. 

This is a rough description of what I am observing, but the behavior is inconsistent. As shown in the video, often it will choose different things from `Content` to render. I cannot reproduce the bug in a clean workspace. Quitting VSCode and restarting it tends to fix the issue, but it will begin to do it again after a couple hours of being open. When it happens, this behavior is not observed across all folders. There is nothing especially strange about the folders it happens in; they contain no more than a dozen direct children, they do not tend to be folders whose direct children have recently been edited, and the workspace itself has around 1000 files total. 

I first noticed this bug after the update to 1.9.0. 

I will attempt to capture more footage of it happening when it starts doing it again. Let me know if I can be of any other assistance!

data.title: Launching VScode from the quick access menu does not correctly inherit system environment variable if a change has been made since first launch.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:31:00.827Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|live-html-previewer|hdg|0.0.1|
|latex-workshop|James-Yu|0.2.13|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.0|
|latex|ms-vscode|0.1.3|
|code-spell-checker|streetsidesoftware|0.17.2|
|vim|vscodevim|0.5.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open an instance of VScode
2. change the PATH environment variable
3. reload VScode observe inability to detect the new PATH changes.

Fixes:

a) load the integrated terminal (powershell) and reset the system the local PATH variable to that of the system i.e. [thanks stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17794507/reload-the-path-in-powershell)
```
$env:Path = [System.Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("Path","Machine") + ";" + System.Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("Path","User")
```
This is only temporary - if i close all instances and then restart VScode then the path variable reverts to the out of date version... going to try Fixes b.
b) Reboot - (hypothesised as this would reseed all processes with the system envs)


Context: 

This was encountered by updating my MiKTeX installation after installing a the latex-workshop extension. I rebooted VScode and noticed that it couldn't detect any pdflatex binary in the PATH variable, loading up an external console I verified that it was accessible. So I killed all VScode windows (I had a second instance open) and reopened and was presented by the same error. Finally I opened up the integrated console in VScode and saw that it had the old PATH env variable so applied Fixes a).

Is it possible there is some persistent console or background process that is hanging on to the out of date?

data.title: Command palette search relevance
data.body:
(vscode 1.9.0)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/159209/22703627/b1202c04-ed19-11e6-9a71-12817035f4da.png)
